sect1.title: Type Juggling
sect1.simpara: PHP does not require (or support) explicit type definition in variable declaration; a variable's type is determined by the context in which the variable is used. That is to say, if a string value is assigned to variable $var, $var becomes a string. If an integer value is then assigned to $var, it becomes an integer.
sect1.para: An example of PHP's automatic type conversion is the addition operator '+'. If either operand is a float, then both operands are evaluated as floats, and the result will be a float. Otherwise, the operands will be interpreted as integers, and the result will also be an integer. Note that this does not change the types of the operands themselves; the only change is in how the operands are evaluated and what the type of the expression itself is.

informalexample.programlisting: <?php $foo = "0"; // $foo is string (ASCII 48) $foo += 2; // $foo is now an integer (2) $foo = $foo + 1.3; // $foo is now a float (3.3) $foo = 5 + "10 Little Piggies"; // $foo is integer (15) $foo = 5 + "10 Small Pigs"; // $foo is integer (15) ?>

sect1.simpara: If the last two examples above seem odd, see String conversion to numbers.
To force a variable to be evaluated as a certain type, see the section on Type casting. To change the type of a variable, see the settype function.
sect1.para: To test any of the examples in this section, use the var_dump function.

note.para: The behaviour of an automatic conversion to array is currently undefined.
Also, because PHP supports indexing into strings via offsets using the same syntax as array indexing, the following example holds true for all PHP versions:

informalexample.programlisting: <?php $a = 'car'; // $a is a string $a[0] = 'b'; // $a is still a string echo $a; // bar ?>

note.para: See the section titled String access by character for more information.

sect2.title: Type Casting
sect2.para: Type casting in PHP works much as it does in C: the name of the desired type is written in parentheses before the variable which is to be cast.

informalexample.programlisting: <?php $foo = 10; // $foo is an integer $bar = (boolean) $foo; // $bar is a boolean ?>

sect2.para: (binary) casting and b prefix forward support was added in PHP 5.2.1
Note that tabs and spaces are allowed inside the parentheses, so the following are functionally equivalent:

informalexample.para: Casting literal strings and variables to binary strings:

note.para: Instead of casting a variable to a string, it is also possible to enclose the variable in double quotes.

informalexample.programlisting:
<?php
$foo = 10;            // $foo is an integer
$str = "$foo";        // $str is a string
$fst = (string) $foo; // $fst is also a string

// This prints out that "they are the same"
if ($fst === $str) {
    echo "they are the same";
}
?>
